{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Islam by country}} According to 2007 statistics released by the [[U.S. Department of State]] concerning '''[[Islam]] in Nicaragua''', there are approximately 1,200 to 1,500 Muslims, mostly [[Sunnis]] who are [[resident aliens]] or [[naturalized|naturalized citizens]] from [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], [[Libya]], and [[Iran]] or natural-born Nicaraguan citizens born to both of the two groups. The Islamic Cultural Center in [[Managua]] serves as the primary ''[[salaat]]'' (prayer) center for Muslims in the city, with approximately 320 men attending on a regular basis. Muslims from [[Granada]], [[Masaya]], [[Le√≥n, Nicaragua|Leon]], and [[Chinandega]] also travel to the Managua center for Friday prayers. Granada, Masaya, and Leon have smaller prayer centers in the homes of prominent local Muslims. In May 2007 the Sunni leader of the Managua prayer center was dismissed, due to the increase in Iranian influence in the Muslim community and was to be replaced by a [[Shi'a]] religious leader. By the end of the reporting period (May 2007) the Shi'a leader had not been identified.<ref>[http://nicaragua.usembassy.gov/religious_2007.html International Religious Freedom 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724182039/http://nicaragua.usembassy.gov/religious_2007.html |date=24 July 2008 }} (Released October 2007, covers period of June 2006 to May 2007)</ref>
==Background==
===Early Immigration=== Muslim immigration occurred in moderate numbers in [[Nicaragua]] in the late 19th century. The majority were [[Palestinian people|Palestinian Arab]] Muslims; the immigration constituted one of the largest waves of immigration to Central America. Although the exact number of Palestinians is not available, Guzm√°n writes ''"it is possible that from the end of the nineteenth century until 1917, when the [[Ottoman Empire]] entered its final decline, during [[World War I]], 40 Palestinian families arrived in Nicaragua"''.<ref name=Guzman>{{cite book | first=Roberto | last=Mar√≠n Guzm√°n | coauthors= | title=A Century of Palestinian Immigration into Central America: A Study of Their Economic and Cultural Contributions | year=2000 | publisher=Editorial Universidad de C.R. | url = | work = | pages =49‚Äì59 | language = |isbn = 9977-67-587-2 }}</ref>
This early wave of immigrants quickly lost their Islamic roots and blended into the local population, often by adopting a Christian heritage due to intermarrying and government pressure. At different points during the 1890s to the 1940s Nicaragua, and many other Latin American countries, established laws or issued ordinances that restricted the entry of [[Arabs]], forbade the stay of Arabs already present in the country and curtailed the expansion of their commercial activities.<ref>{{cite book | first=Christina | last=Civantos | coauthors= | title=Between Argentines and Arabs: Argentine orientalism, Arab immigrants, and the writing of identity | year=2005 | publisher=SUNY Press | url = | work = | isbn = 0-7914-6601-9| page =224 }}</ref>
===Immigration: 1960s through 2000=== [[File:Palestinian March in Nicaragua.jpg|thumb|right|Palestinians celebrating the 10th anniversary of the Nicaraguan revolution in Managua waving Palestine and [[Sandinista]] flags.]] The second group of immigrants in the 1960s was better educated, but not any more oriented towards Islam than the first. This group was affected by two major events in Nicaragua: the [[1972 Nicaragua earthquake]], and the [[Nicaraguan Revolution]] in 1979. At that time, many of the former Palestinians immigrated to North America or returned to Palestine. Those that stayed suffered greatly and their families were further assimilated into Christianity. The latest and smallest group of √©migr√©s was in the early 1990s. Many of these were immigrants returning to Nicaragua who had since become more aware of their Muslim heritage from exposure in North America or Palestine. These immigrants also possessed a stronger Islamic identity than previous groups, enabling an Islamic reawakening by the community.<ref>''The Islamic Bulletin'', [http://www.islamicbulletin.com/newsletters/issue_16/nicaragua.aspx Islam in Nicaragua]</ref>
By 2000 it was estimated that there were 500 families of Palestine Arabs and Palestinian descendants in Nicaragua. The Palestinians that arrived in Nicaragua were mostly Christians and a small number of Muslims, the majority of which came from rural villages near [[Ramallah]], [[Jerusalem]], [[Beit Jala]] and [[Bethlehem]]. The total population of Palestinians in Nicaragua ranks as the largest Arab community in Central America.
===Recent developments=== According to Fahmi Hassan, President of the 'Asociaci√≥n Cultural Nicarag√ºense-Isl√°mica, the [[Muslim]] population consists primarily of Arabs who immigrated from [[Palestinian territories]] and [[Lebanon]], in addition to a number of indigenous converts.<ref>Edwin S√°nchez, [http://archivo.elnuevodiario.com.ni/2004/marzo/14-marzo-2004/nacional/nacional1.html ''Primer Im√°n de Nicaragua''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310212255/http://archivo.elnuevodiario.com.ni/2004/marzo/14-marzo-2004/nacional/nacional1.html |date=10 March 2007 }}. ''El Nuevo Diario''. Domingo 14 de Marzo de 2004</ref> In 1999, the first ''[[masjid]]'' (mosque) was constructed in the country on a parcel of land measuring three thousand meters in the [[San Juan del Sur|San Juan]] district (Ciudad Jardin) with a capacity for nearly one thousand people. The ''masjid'' provides introductory courses on Islamic doctrine, as well as a place for performance of the congregational Friday prayer (''[[Jumu'ah|Salaat al-Jummah]]'') and [[Ramadan]] activities. Although the small Muslim community initially lacked finances, they were assisted by contributions from a delegation of [[Islam in Panama|Panamanian Muslims]]. Besides its characteristic ''[[minar]]'', the liturgical office has a library, prayer room, administrative office, children's area, and a school. Religious seminars are offered for both men and women; Spanish language pamphlets are also distributed.<ref>Elhamalawy, Salma [http://www.islamonline.net/English/artculture/2003/10/article10.shtml ''Celebrating Ramadan from Chile to China'']. October 2003</ref> Additionally, another new Islamic Center was recently inaugurated, called the ''Centro Cultural Isl√°mico Nicarag√ºense''. It is operated by a group of [[Shia Islam|Shiite Muslims]] and their main goal is the propagation of Islamic teachings. Population of Shiite Muslims existed in Nicaragua from migration of Iranian refugees escaping [[Iranian Revolution]] of 1979 and escaping turmoil of [[Iran‚ÄìIraq War]] of the 1980s, the Iran‚ÄìNicaragua ties strengthened the influence of Shia Islam. Most Shi'ite Muslim Nicaraguans are of Iranian blood, they may still speak [[Persian language|Persian]] and/or other [[languages of Iran|Iranian language]], aside from Arabic and Spanish. in the 2018 protests in Managua there was little identified participation by the Muslim community

[[Islam]] is the religion of about 35.2% of the people of [[Tanzania]]. On the mainland, Muslim communities are concentrated in coastal areas, with some large Muslim majorities also in inland urban areas especially and along the former caravan routes. More than 99% of the population of the [[Zanzibar]] [[Zanzibar Archipelago|archipelago]] is [[Muslim]]. The majority of [[Muslim]]s in [[Tanzania]] are [[Sunni]] of [[Shafi]] school of [[jurisprudence]], with unusually significant [[Shia]] and [[Ahmadi]] minorities in sub-Saharan Africa. According to Pew research center, two-thirds of the [[Muslim]] population of [[Tanzania]] is [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]], while the rest is either [[Shia]] (20%) or [[Ahmadi]] (15%).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pewforum.org/uploadedFiles/Topics/Religious_Affiliation/Muslim/the-worlds-muslims-full-report.pdf | title=The World's Muslims: Unity and Diversity | accessdate=August 14, 2012 | date=August 9, 2012 | publisher=Pew Forum on Religious & Public life}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 105-DOA0232, Deutsch-Ostafrika, Arabische Moschee.jpg|thumb|The [[Great Mosque of Kilwa]] is one of the earliest surviving mosques in the [[African Great Lakes]].]]
The earliest concrete evidence of a [[Muslim]] presence in the [[African Great Lakes]] is the foundation of a mosque in [[Shanga, Pate Island|Shanga]] on [[Pate Island]], where gold, silver and copper coins dated from 830 were found during an excavation in the 1980s. Islam arrived to Tanzania with the [[Arab slave trade]]rs. The route from Ujiji at the shore of Lake Tanganyika to Bagamoyo, just opposite of Zanzibar on main land Tanzania was one of the main routes of Muslim slave routes according to UNESCO data.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists/2095/|title=The Central Slave and Ivory Trade Route - UNESCO World Heritage Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|last=Centre|date=|website=whc.unesco.org|accessdate=22 April 2018}}</ref>
The history of Islam in the country can be traced to the establishment of the [[Kilwa Sultanate]] in the 10th century by [[Ali ibn al-Hassan Shirazi]],<ref>ÿ¥ÿßŸÉÿ± ŸÖÿµÿ∑ŸÅŸâ, ''ŸÖŸàÿ≥Ÿàÿπÿ© ÿØŸàÿßŸÑ ÿßŸÑÿπÿßŸÑŸÖ ÿßŸÑÿ£ÿ≥ŸÑÿßŸÖŸä Ÿàÿ±ÿ¨ÿßŸÑŸáÿß ÿßŸÑÿ¨ÿ≤ÿ° ÿßŸÑÿ´ÿßŸÑÿ´'', (ÿØÿßÿ± ÿßŸÑÿπŸÑŸÖ ŸÑŸÑŸÖŸÑÿßŸäŸäŸÜ: 1993), p.1360</ref> a [[Persian people|Persian]] prince of [[Shiraz]].<ref>James Hastings, ''Encyclopedia of Religion and Ethics Part 24'', (Kessinger Publishing: 2003), p.847</ref>

{{BLP sources|date=September 2015}} {{notability|Academics|date=September 2015}} '''John Christopher Thomas''' (born c. 1955) is a [[theologian]] within the [[Pentecostal]] movement and the Clarence J. Abbott Professor of Biblical Studies at the [[Pentecostal Theological Seminary]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ptseminary.net/administrative-ministry-team/ranked-faculty/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-09-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150915014900/http://www.ptseminary.net/administrative-ministry-team/ranked-faculty/ |archivedate=2015-09-15 |df= }}</ref>
Thomas received the B.A. degree from [[Lee University|Lee College]] in 1976, his M.A. from the [[Church of God School of Theology]] in 1977, the M.Div. from [[Ashland Theological Seminary]] in 1978, a Th.M. from [[Princeton Theological Seminary]] in 1979 and a Ph.D. from the [[University of Sheffield]] in 1990. Thomas has been a member of the full-time faculty of the [http://www.ptseminary.edu/ Pentecostal Theological Seminary] since 1982.
As a New Testament scholar, Thomas' work has been published in the journals ''New Testament Studies'', ''Novum Testamentum'', ''Zeitschrift fur die neutestamentliche Wissenschaft'', and ''Journal for the Study or the New Testament''. He authored a study titled ''Footwashing in John 13 and the Johannine Community'', published a collection of his essays, ''Ministry and Theology: Studies for the Church and Its Leaders'', and wrote a commentary titled ''The Apocalypse: A Literary and Theological Commentary'' (2012) and a monograph on healing titled ''The Devil, Disease, and Deliverance: Origins of Illness in New Testament Thought'' (2011). Several other books of his include: ''He Loved Them until the End: The Farewell Materials in the Gospel according to John'' (2003); ''The Pentecostal Commentary on 1 John, 2 John, 3 John'' (2004); and ''The Spirit of the New Testament'' (2005).
Thomas serves as Editor-in-Chief of the ''[[Journal of Pentecostal Theology]]'' and Supplement Series, and serves as General Editor of the ''Pentecostal Commentary Series''. He is also Associate Director of the Centre for Pentecostal and Charismatic Studies, Bangor University, Wales. In 1992, Ashland Theological Seminary named him Alumnus of the Year. From 1997 to 1998, Thomas served as the President of the [[Society for Pentecostal Studies]].
Thomas has also approached theological and literary study of the [[Book of Mormon]] in his 2016 book ''A Pentecostal Reads the Book of Mormon: A Literary and Theological Introduction''.<ref>[http://www.mormoninterpreter.com/category/review/ Review of this book for the journal Interpreter]</ref> ==References== {{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=February 2016}} '''Mahatma''' ({{IPAc-en|m|…ô|Àà|h|…ëÀê|t|m|…ô|,_|-|Àà|h|√¶|t|-}}) is [[Sanskrit]] for "Great Soul" (‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ''mahƒÅtmƒÅ'': ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ ''mahƒÅ'' (great) + ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ç or ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§® ''ƒÅtman'' [soul]). It is similar in usage to the modern English term [[saint]].{{Cite NIE|wstitle=MahƒÅtma |year=1905}} This [[epithet]] is commonly applied to prominent people like [[Basava|Basaveshwara]]{{Cite web|url=https://archivepmo.nic.in/drmanmohansingh/speech-details.php?nodeid=333|title=PM's address on the occasion of release of Commemorative Coin in honour of Mahatma Basaveshwara : Speeches : Prime Minister of India - Dr. Manmohan Singh (May 22, 2004 - 26th May 2014)|website=archivepmo.nic.in|access-date=2018-08-07}} (1105-1167), [[Mahatma Gandhi|Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi]] (1869-1948), Munshiram (later [[Swami Shraddhananda]], 1856‚Äì1926), [[Lalon Shah]] (1772‚Äì1890), [[Ayyankali]] (1863-1941) and [[Jyotirao Phule]] (1827‚Äì1890). It has also been historically used for a class of Jain scholars. ==Mohandas Gandhi's title "Mahatma"== {{Main article|Mahatma Gandhi}} According to [[Rabindranath Tagore]] is said to have used on March 6, 1915, this title for Gandhi.Dutta, Krishna and Andrew Robinson, ''Rabindranath Tagore: An Anthology'', p. 2 Some claim that he was called Mahatma by the residents of Gurukul Kangadi in April 1915,[http://inextlive.jagran.com/mahatma-gandhi-201210010040 ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§á‡§∏ ‡§§‡§∞‡§π ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§¨‡§® ‡§ó‡§è, 01-Oct-2012] and he in turn called the founder Munshiram a Mahatma (who later became [[Swami Shraddhananda]]). However, a document honoring him with the title "Mahatma" on Jan 21, 1915, in [[Jetpur, Navagadh|Jetpur]], Gujarat, by [[Nautamlal Bhagavanji Mehta|Nautamlal Bhagvanji Mehta]] is preserved at the National Gandhi Museum in New Delhi, India.[http://gandhimuseum.org/site/sections/photo-section/ National Gandhi Museum, New Delhi]; [http://www.kamdartree.com/index.php?id=57&stitle=Mahatma%20&%20Kamdars KamdarTree.com] This document remains the earliest record of the title "Mahatma" being bestowed upon Gandhi. The use of the term Mahatma in [[Jainism]] to denote a class of lay priests, has been noted since the 17th century. A Mahatma is someone who practices [[Trikaranasuddhi]].{{cite journal|last1=Sankar R N|first1=Ajith|title=Ascertaining Linkages between Trikaranasuddhi and ‚ÄòTapping Spirituality as the Context of Leadership‚Äô|journal=IPE Journal of Management|date=Jul‚ÄìDec 2012|volume=1|issue=2|pages=81‚Äì105|ssrn=2212138}} =={{anchor|Theosophy}} Theosophy== The word, used in a technical sense, was popularized in [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|theosophical]] literature in the late 19th century, when Madame [[Helena Blavatsky]], one of the founders of the [[Theosophical Society]], claimed that her teachers were [[adept]]s (or Mahatmas) who reside in [[Asia]]. According to the Theosophical teachings, the Mahatmas are not disembodied beings, but highly evolved people involved in overseeing the spiritual growth of individuals and the development of civilizations. Blavatsky was the first person in modern times to claim contact with these Adepts, especially the "Masters" [[Koot Hoomi]] and [[Morya (Theosophy)|Morya]]. [[Alvin Boyd Kuhn]] wrote about mahƒÅtmƒÅs:Kuhn (1930), ‚Äì p. 147.
The Masters whom Theosophy presents to us are simply high-ranking students in life's school of experience. They are members of our own evolutionary group, not visitants from the celestial spheres. They are supermen only in that they have attained knowledge of the laws of life and mastery over its forces with which we are still struggling.
In September and October 1880, Blavatsky visited [[Alfred Percy Sinnett|A. P. Sinnett]] at [[Shimla|Simla]] in northern India. Sinnett wrote ''[[The Occult World]]'' (1881) and [[Esoteric Buddhism (book)|''Esoteric Buddhism'']] (1883). There has been a great deal of controversy concerning the existence of adepts. Blavatsky's critics have doubted the existence of her Masters. See, for example, W. E. Coleman's "exposes". After Blavatsky's death in 1891, numerous individuals have claimed to be in contact with her Adept Teachers. These individuals have stated that they are new "messengers" of the Masters and they have conveyed various esoteric teachings.[http://blavatskyarchives.com/latermessengers.htm Madame Blavatsky & the Latter-Day Messengers of the Masters]. Currently, various [[New Age]], [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]], and religious organizations refer to them as [[Ascended Master]]s, although their character and teachings are in several respects different from those described by Theosophical writers.Leadbeater, C. W. ''The Masters and the Path''. Adyar, India: Theosophical Publishing House, 1929 (Reprint: Kessinger Publishing, 1997).Partridge, Christopher ed. ''New Religions: A Guide: New Religious Movements, Sects and Alternative Spiritualities'' Oxford University Press, USA 2004. Some individuals{{who|date=August 2017}} believe that Mahatma Maitreya (also called World Teacher) will make contact with all Humanity in January 2017. ==Divine Light Mission== The [[Divine Light Mission]] (DLM) was a [[Contemporary Sant Mat movements|Sant Mat]]-based movement begun in India in the 1930s by [[Hans Ji Maharaj]] and formally incorporated in 1960. The DLM had as many as 2,000 Mahatmas, all from India or Tibet, who taught the DLM's secret meditation techniques called "Knowledge". The Mahatmas, called "realised souls",Price, Maeve (1979): The Divine Light Mission as a social organization. (1) Sociological Review, 27, Page 279-296 or "apostles", also served as local leaders.[[Saul V. Levine|Levine, Saul V.]] in {{cite book |author=Galanter, Marc |title=Cults and New Religious Movements: A Report of the American Psychiatric Association |publisher=American Psychiatric Pub., Inc |location= |year=1989 |pages= |isbn=0-89042-212-5 |oclc= |doi=}} After Hans Ji's death in 1966 his youngest son, [[Prem Rawat]] (known then as Guru Maharaj Ji or Bagyogeshwar), succeeded him. The young guru appointed some new Mahatmas, including one from the United States. In one incident, a prominent Indian Mahatma nearly beat a man to death in Detroit for throwing a pie at the guru.{{cite news|title=Who's Who in Gurus|first=Dennis |last=Bartel|page= 55|work=Harper's|date=November 1983}} In the early 1980s, Prem Rawat replaced the Divine Light Mission organization with the Elan Vital and replaced the Mahatmas with initiators. The initiators did not have the revered status of the Mahatmas, and they were drawn mostly from Western followers. In the 2000s, the initiators were replaced by a video in which Rawat teaches the techniques himself. ==In popular culture== [[W. C. Fields#At Paramount|W.C. Fields]] used the pseudonym Mahatma Kane Jeeves when writing the script for ''[[The Bank Dick]]'' (1940), in a play on both the word "Mahatma" and a phrase an aristocrat might use when addressing a servant, before leaving the house: "My hat, my cane, Jeeves". ==Jain Mahatmas== {{Further|Yati}} [[File:MewarRamayanaP22MahatmaHirananda.jpg|thumb|Mewad Ramayana manuscript: The colophon in red: states text was written by the Mahatma Hirananda, was commissioned by Acarya Jasvant for the library of Maharana Jagat Singh I of Mewar. Finished on Friday 25 November 1650]] Among the [[Jain]]s the term Mahatma is used for class for scholars who are householders. ===Mahatma Hirananda of Mewad=== The Mewad Ramayana[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-26670449 In pictures: Stunning Ramayana manuscript goes digital, BBC, 21 March 2014] described as "one of the most beautiful manuscripts in the world"[http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/indiaatlse/2014/06/13/mewar-ramayana/ The Mewar Ramayana at the British Library: How the complete digital version came to be] has been digitally reunited after being split between organisations in the UK and India for over 150 years, by the British Library and CSMVS Museum in Mumbai. The colophon states that the text, commissioned by Acarya Jasvant for the library of Maharana Jagat Singh I of Mewar, was written by the Mahatma Hirananda, was finished on Friday 25 November 1650.[http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/ttp/ramayana/accessible/pages21and22.html#content Ramayana - Pages 21 and 22 (British Library Add. MSS 15296-15297 and IO San 3621)] Mahatma Hirananda being a Jain scribe, incorporated traditional Jain scribal elements into the manuscript.[http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/ttp/ramayana/accessible/pages3and4.html#content Ramayana - Pages 3 and 4] ===Jain Mahatmas in the [[Dabestan-e Mazaheb]]=== The famous [[Dabestan-e Mazaheb]] often attributed to one Mohsin Fani, written around 1655 CE. is a text written in the Mughal period that describes various religions and philosophies the author encountered.[https://books.google.com/books?id=cxJgAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA1&dq=THE+DABIST%C3%81N,+OR+SCHOOL+OF+MANNERS&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=4#v=onepage&q=THE%20DABIST%C3%81N%2C%20OR%20SCHOOL%20OF%20MANNERS&f=false The Dabist√°n: Or, School of Manners: The Religious Beliefs, Observances, Philosophic Opinions and Social Customs of the Nations of the East, Fani Muhsin, Translated by David Shea, Anthony Troyer, Publisher, M. Walter Dunne, 1901 p. 275-276] Its Section 11 is dedicated to Jainism. It states: "Similar to the durvishes of both classes (Srivaras and [[Yati|Jatis]]) is a third sect, called Mah√°-√°tma; they have the dress and appearance of Jatis; only they do not pluck their hair with tweezers, but cut it. They accumulate money, cook their meal in their houses, drink cold water, and take to them a wife." The term Mahatma was thus used for priest/scholars who were not celibate. The present [[Persian language|Persian]] edition of the text by Rezazadeh Malik attributes it to the son and successor of [[Azar Kayvan]], 'Kay Khosrow Esfandiyar'. ==Criticism== [[K. Paul Johnson]] in his booksJohnson (1994), Johnson (1995) ‚Äì p. 49. speculates that the "Masters" that [[Helena Blavatsky|Blavatsky]] wrote about and produced letters from were actually idealizations of people who were her [[mentor]]s. Aryel Sanat,"Aryel Sanat (Miguel Angel Sanabria) is currently Adjunct Professor in the Department of Philosophy and Religion at the American University in Washington, D.C." // [https://books.google.ru/books?id=0dHP2f_6k4YC&dq=editions:jYIKHxJulMgC&hl=ru&source=gbs_navlinks_s About author of ''The inner life of Krishnamurti'' in 1999.] author of ''The inner life of Krishnamurti: private passion and perennial wisdom'', wrote that Johnson "claims in all of his books that there were no Masters at all in early [[Theosophical Society|[Theosophical Society]]] history, & that [[Helena Blavatsky|[Helena Blavatsky]]] '''invented''' them (as others had claimed she had invented her travels)." Sanat wrote that Johnson "'''deliberately''' ignores the main sources of evidence for their real physical existence."See [http://www.theos-talk.com/archives/200005/tt00087.html ''Theosophy World.''] What Sanat thought these were is not made quite clear. ==Sources== * French, Brendan James (2000) [http://hdl.handle.net/2123/7147 ''The theosophical masters: an investigation into the conceptual domains of H.P. Blavatsky and C.W. Leadbeater.''] PhD thesis, [[University of Sydney]], Department of Religious Studies. Sydney. * Johnson, K. Paul (1994) ''The Masters Revealed: Madam Blavatsky and Myth of the Great White Brotherhood.'' Albany, New York: State University of New York Press. * Johnson, K. Paul (1995) ''Initiates of Theosophical Masters.'' Albany, New York: State University of New York Press. * Kalnitsky, Arnold (2003) [http://hdl.handle.net/10500/2108 ''The Theosophical Movement of the Nineteenth Century: The Legitimation of the Disputable and the Entrenchment of the Disreputable.''] [[University of South Africa]]. Dissertation: 443 pp. * Kuhn, Alvin Boyd (1930) [http://downloads.members.tripod.com/~pc93/tsphyraw.htm ''Theosophy: A Modern Revival of Ancient Wisdom.''] PhD Thesis. Whitefish, Montana: Kessinger Publishing. {{ISBN|978-1-56459-175-3}}. ==Footnotes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *Dutta, Krishna and Andrew Robinson. ''Rabindranath Tagore: An Anthology.'' Picador/Macmillan: London, 1997. ==External links== {{NIE Poster|year=1905|MahƒÅtma}} *[http://mahatmaletters.net/ The theosophical Mahatmas and Their Letters] {{DEFAULTSORT:Mahatma}} [[Category:Theosophy]] [[Category:Theosophical philosophical concepts]] [[Category:Titles in India]] [[Category:Mahatma Gandhi]]

[[File:Medinet Madi 05.JPG|thumb|150px|The ruins of Medinet Maadi temple]] [[File:Medinet Madi 16.JPG|thumb|150px|Amenemhat III's cartouche at Medinet Maadi temple]]
'''Medinet Madi''' is a site in the southwestern [[Faiyum]] region of [[Egypt]] with the remains of a Greco-Roman town where a [[Egyptian temple|temple]] of the cobra-goddess [[Renenutet]] (a harvest deity) was founded during the reigns of [[Amenemhat III]] and [[Amenemhat IV]] (1855‚Äì1799 BC). It was later expanded and embellished during the Greco-Roman period. In the Middle Kingdom the town was called Dja, in the Ptolemaic and Roman Periods it was called Narmuthis.
== The town == In the Middle Kingdom the town was called ''Dja'', but not much is known about the town in this period apart from the well preserved temple. The temple still functioned in the New Kingdom. King [[Merenptah]] placed a statue of himself into the temple. After the New Kingdom the place was abandoned. People settled here again in Ptolemaic times. The Ptolemaic town was laid out on a grid pattern and is about 1000 √ó 600 m big.<ref>Paolo Davoli: ''L'archaeologia urbana nel Fayoum id et√† ellenistica e romana'', Naples 1998, 223</ref> The main temples are in the Western part of the town. There is a long processional way going north to South. The town never had walls. However under emperor [[Diocletian]] there was built a castrum north east of the town. The fortress (50 √ó 50 m)is square with the main entrance in the South. At each corner there was a tower.<ref>Bresciani, Giammarusti: ''I templi di Medinet Madi nel Fayum'', 31-39</ref> Here was stationed the ''Cohors IV Numidarum''. In Byzantine Times the population moved to the southern part of the town. Several churches were erected. The town was still occupied after the Arab conquest of Egypt, but was abandoned after the ninth century.<ref>Edda Bresciani, Ali Radwan, Antonio Giammarusti, Hisham el-Leithy: ''Medinet Madi, Archaeological Guide'', Verona 2010, {{ISBN|9788887177893}}, 14-15</ref>
==The Renenutet temple (temple A) == The dark sandstone inner part of the temple consists of a small papyrus-columned hall leading to a sanctuary comprising three chapels, each containing statues of deities. One column bears the name of Amenemhat III, the other with the name of Amenemhat IV. Both naming also Renenutet.<ref>Bresciani, Giammarusti: ''I templi di Medinet Madi nel Fayum'', 78</ref> The central chapel incorporated a large statue of Renenutet, with Amenemhat III and Amenemhat IV standing on either side of her. In the inscriptions, the temple is simply called ''temple of Renenutet''. Renenutet is called ''The living Renenutet of Dja''.
[[File:MadinatMadiLeftCLeftWall.jpg|thumb|Scene on the East wall of the West chapel: Amenemhat III before Renenutet]] The reliefs in the first hall are not well preserved, but they include a scene showing a king and the goddess Seshat, founding the temple.<ref>Bresciani, Giammarusti: ''I templi di Medinet Madi nel Fayum'', 80</ref> Behind the entrance room there follows another one, that is also all around decorated with reliefs. On the South side there is a scene showing Amenemhat III in front of Renenutet. The latter is depicted as standing women with a snake head. Between both is shown in a much smaller scale the ''king's daughter'' [[Neferuptah]]. At the back of this room, on the North side, there are the three chapels. The first one, on the West side, is dedicated to Renenutet. She appears as the main deity at the back of the chapel. On the side walls are shown on the West side Sobek, and on the East side Renenutet.<ref>Bresciani, Giammarusti: ''I templi di Medinet Madi nel Fayum'', 91-95</ref> The second chapel was dedicated to Renenutet and Sobek. Renenutet appears on the West wall and on the back (North) wall, standing behind king Amenemhat III. The king is standing in front of Sobek, who also appears on the East wall in front of the same king. On the East wall appears Sobek again. The last chapel was again mainly dedicated to Renenutet. She appears on the West and on the back wall in front of Amenemhat III, while on the East wall Sobek is standing in front of a king.<ref>Bresciani, Giammarusti: ''I templi di Medinet Madi nel Fayum'', 96-102</ref>
The Ptolemaic parts of the temple comprise a paved processional way passing through an eight-columned kiosk leading to a portico and transverse vestibule. It has been suggested that the unusually good preservation of this temple complex, excavated by a team of archaeologists from the [[University of Milan]] in the 1930s, may have been due simply to its relative seclusion.
==Temple B== Temple B was built at the back of temple A with the main entrance facing to the North. The plan of this building is similar to that of temple A. There is an open broad courtyard at the front. There follows a hall and at the back there are three chapels. The central chapel has a niche at the back. The temple was dedicated to Isis-Thermouthis (Thermouthis is the Greek name for Renenutet). The temple's decoration is unfinished. There are some figures carved as reliefs on the temple walls. Two badly preserved figures flanking the entrance. On the leftside of the facade was carved a sitting figure, that was never finished.<ref>Bresciani, Giammarusti: ''I templi di Medinet Madi nel Fayum'', 159-167</ref>
==Temple C== [[File:MadinatMadiTempleCChapel.jpg|thumb|The main chapel of Temple C with the two naoi]] Temple C was so called by the excavators. It was dedicated to the cult of two crocodile mummies. The temple complex was excavated from 1995 to 1999. The temple lies east of the Renenutet temple with the main entrance facing the latter temple complex. It dates to the Ptolemaic Period and was found well preserved. The walls are still up to four meters high. The temple proper consists of a small courtyard with a chapel behind it. The chapel contains two naoi. In each of them was found the mummy of a crocodile. In front of the temple is a bigger courtyard and there are on both sides buildings. They were perhaps for economical use. North of the temple was excavated a vaulted chamber. The interior is divided into two parts by a stone wall. Attached to the wall there is a basin. In the basin where found more than thirty crocodile eggs. This might indicate that this vaulted room was once a nursery for crocodiles. The temple complex was in use till the Fourth century AD and then abounded. <ref>Edda Bresciani, Ali Radwan, Antonio Giammarusti, Hisham el-Leithy: ''Medinet Madi, Archaeological Guide'', Verona 2010, {{ISBN|9788887177893}}, 44-47</ref>
==2006 excavations== Medinet Madi is "the only intact temple still existing from the Middle Kingdom" according to [[Zahi Hawass]], a former Secretary-General of the [[Supreme Council of Antiquities]] (SCA).<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070413171327/http://www.metimes.com/storyview.php?StoryID=20060407-033056-4219r Middle East Times: ''Egypt finds clue to ancient temple's secret''] April 7, 2006</ref> The temple's foundations, administrative buildings, granaries and residences were recently uncovered by an Egyptian archaeological expedition in early 2006.
==Coptic texts== [[Coptic language|Coptic]] texts were uncovered near Medinet Maadi in 1928. Among them was the [[Manichaeism|Manichaean]] Psalm-book that includes the [[Psalms of Thomas]].
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Edda Bresciani, Antonio Giammarusti: ''I templi di Medinet Madi nel Fayum'', Pisa 2015, {{ISBN|9788867414529}} *Achille Vogliano, ''Primo (e secondo) rapporto degli scavi condotti dalla missione archeologica d'Egitto della R. Universit√† di Milano nella zona di Madinet Maadi'', 1935‚Äì6 (Milan, 1936‚Äì7). *R. Naumann, "Der Tempel des Mittleren Reiches in Medinet Madi", ''MDAIK'' 8 (1939), 185‚Äì9. *Ian Shaw and Paul Nicholson, ''The Dictionary of Ancient Egypt'', 178 *Medinet Madi website: https://web.archive.org/web/20140227140432/http://www.medinetmadi.org/

{{Infobox person | name = Melchor Ferrer Dalmau | image = Melchor Ferrer.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Melchor Ferrer Dalmau | birth_date = 1888 | birth_place = [[Matar√≥]], Spain | death_date = 1965 | death_place = [[Valencia]], Spain | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = historian, publisher | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = publisher, writer | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Carlism]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }} '''Melchor Ferrer Dalmau''' (1888-1965) was a Spanish [[historian]] and a [[Carlist]] militant. He is known mostly as principal author of a massive, 30-volume series titled ''Historia del tradicionalismo espa√±ol'', considered fundamental work of reference for any student of Carlism. Ferrer is recognized also as "[[Journalist|periodista]]", chief editor of one national and few local [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]] dailies and contributor to a number of others. Politically he maintained a low profile, though periodically he was member of the party executive and during internal party strife of the early 1960s his support might have tipped the balance in favor of the progressist faction.
==Family and youth== [[File:Collegio de Valldemia, around 1870.jpg|thumb|left|Ferrer Arman teaching, 1870]] Ferrer counts among the oldest and most common names in [[Catalonia]]; one family lived in the town of [[Matar√≥]], where in the 14th century it was first noted when turning from "lo ferrer" to "lo Fferrer".<ref>Ramon Reixach i Puig, ''Els Ferrer de Matar√≥ i el realisme constitucional catal√°'', [in:] ''Fulls de Museu Arxiu de Santa Maria'' 81 (2005), p. 4</ref> They grew into prominence as traders and bankers in the 15th century, dubbed "primera familia de patricis de Matar√≥". Some of them held high posts in the [[Principality of Catalonia|Principality]], e.g. emerging as its general treasurers in the 16th century<ref>Reixach i Puig 2005, p. 15</ref> and becoming key representatives of the emerging Catalan [[bourgeoisie]] in the 17th and 18th century. The family got very branched later on, also in the [[Latin America]].<ref>''Los Ferrer de C√≥rdoba'', [in:] ''Historia y Genealog√≠a Sudamericana'' blog 15.12.14, available [http://geneasud.blogspot.com/2014/12/los-ferrer-de-cordoba.html here]</ref> None of the sources consulted specifies which branch Melchor descended from and little is known about his grandfather, Antonio Ferrer, a cord manufacturer ("cordonero").<ref>a possibly related Pelegr√≠n Ferrer, following a spell in [[Cuba]] returned to Matar√≥ to become the first director of a newly founded [[Maristes Valldemia|Colegio de Valldemia]], Jaume Vellvehi i Alrimira, ''La Renaixenca a Matar√≥: el Collegi Valldemia'', [in:] ''Estudis Mataronins'' 23 (2006), p. 135</ref>
The father of Melchor, [[Antonio Ferrer Arman]] (1845?-1899),<ref>Vellvehi i Alrimira 2006, pp. 135-136</ref> in the 1860s studied engineering in [[Barcelona]]<ref>and during his academic years was active in Ateneo Catalan de Clase Obrera, ''La Corona'' 09.10.63, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026772867&page=8 here]; he was later co-founder of Ateneo in Matar√≥ and became its treasurer, Francesc Enrich i Reg√°s, ''Josep Garc√≠a i Oliver, destacat promotor de cultura a Matar√≥'', [in:] ''Fulls de Museu Arxiu de Santa Maria'' 16 (1983), p. 28</ref> In 1870 he applied for a job at Instituto de Tarragona but failed,<ref>''La Gaceta Industrial'' 30.04.70, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0031388385&page=14 here]</ref> eventually he landed a teaching position in the Valldemia college, which at that time was already run by the [[Piarists]].<ref>''Documentaci√≥n fotogr√°fica'', [in:] ''Fulls de Museu Arxiu de Santa Maria'' 100 (2011), p. 46, available [http://www.raco.cat/index.php/FullsMASMM/article/viewFile/243864/357472 here]</ref> Though during his youth he demonstrated some penchant for [[Liberalism in Spain|Liberal ideas]],<ref>as a student Ferrer Arman signed a public letter hailing secular education and aimed against schools run by religious orders, ''La Iberia'' 14.04.64, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001245420&page=2 here]</ref> during the [[Third Carlist War]] he sided with the legitimists and volunteered to Carlist troops; details of his service are unknown, except that he grew to an officer and served under command of [[Rafael Tristany]].<ref>''El tatarabuelo carlista de Augusto Ferrer Delmau'', [in:] ''Somatemps'' service 24.05.17, available [https://somatemps.me/2017/05/24/el-tatarabuelo-carlista-de-augusto-ferrer-dalmau/ here]</ref> Having returned to Matar√≥ in the mid-1880s he became first headmaster of the newly founded Escuela de Artes y Oficiales<ref>''Industria y Invenciones'' 10.12.86, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001462792&page=7es here]</ref> and remained at this post until his death,<ref>''Annuario-Riera'' 1898, p. 634, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004961507&page=666 here]</ref> teaching mathematics.<ref>Vellvehi i Alrimira 2006, p. 135</ref> In the 1890s he was also active as ingeniero municipal,<ref>''Annuario-Riera'' 1898, p. 631, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004961507&page=663 here]</ref> land surveyor and tonnage inspector,<ref>''Annuario-Riera'' 1899, p. 656, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004970926&page=730 here]</ref> co-founder of Associaci√≥ Art√≠stich-Arqueol√≥gica Mataronesa<ref>Vellvehi i Alrimira 2006, p. 135</ref> and author of semi-scientific works, like ''Geometria anal√≠tica'' (1898). He is counted among local Matar√≥ intellectuals who contributed to conservative Catholic [[Catalanism]] in the area, collaborating e.g. with [[Josep Puig i Cadafalch]].<ref>Jaume Vellvehi i Altimira, ''Aproximaci√≥ als or√≠gens del catalanisme al Maresme (1859-1902)'', [in:] ''Sessi√≥ d‚ÄôEstudis Mataronins'' 19 (2002), p. 83</ref> Ferrer Arman married Teresa Dalmau Gual, originating from [[Matanzas]] in Cuba;<ref>see Ferrer‚Äôs birth certificate, available [https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9f/Certificado_nacimiento_Melchor_Ferrer1.jpg here]</ref> nothing is known about her family, apart from the fact that they were also of Catalan origin and may have had a [[Merchant vessel|Naviera]] business.<ref>which disappeared after the [[Treaty of Paris (1898)|Spanish loss of Cuba]].</ref> [[File:Ferrer Dalmau pintando las guerras carlistas.jpg|thumb|[[Augusto Ferrer-Dalmau|Ferrer-Dalmau Nieto]] at work, 2013]] The couple had at least 4 children; Melchor was born among the youngest ones.<ref>Mar√≠a Rosa Ferrer Dalmau was born in 1880, compare ''La Naci√≥n'' 28.01.29, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026260492&page=12 here]</ref> His older brothers, Antonio and Augusto, graduated as engineers and developed own textile and chemical businesses in Barcelona and Valencia.<ref>compare e.g. ''Industria Textil'' 1 (1936), available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0005000220&page=21 here], or ''El Financiero'' 10.09.20, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0025435885&page=6 here], or ''Bibliograf√≠a'' 1/3 (1919), available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0025596368&page=23 here]</ref> Melchor was first educated in the Matar√≥ Piarist college<ref>''ABC'' 13.06.65, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1965/06/13/070.html here]</ref> and then in Instituto de Barcelona.<ref>R.S.H., ''Historia del Tradicionalismo Espa√±ol de Melchor Ferrer Dalmau'', [in:] ''Revista de Historia Militar'' 55 (1983), p. 162</ref> Like his siblings he trained to become an engineer and received technical education at [[School of Engineering of Terrassa|Escuela de Ingenieros Industriales y Textiles]] in the nearby [[Terrassa]].<ref>Jos√© M. Mundet Gifre, ''El carlismo y su historia'', [in:] ''La Vanguardia'' 03.01.80, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1980/01/03/pagina-29/32898271/pdf.html here]</ref> It is not clear if he graduated, yet Melchor has never pursued a related career; in 1910 he commenced co-operation with Catalan journals. In 1920 he married Paquita Rubio Garc√≠a; nothing is known about her except that she came from a military family.<ref>''La Epoca'' 08.01.20, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000926879&page=2 here], also ''El Globo'' 14.01.20, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001468701&page=2 here]</ref> The couple remained childess, yet Melchor and his sister-in-law<ref>strictly speaking the sister of his sister-in-law; Melchor's older brother Augusto was married to Ana Bonet Basang√©; Elvira was her sister</ref> Elvira Bonet had one son, Xavier Ferrer Bonet, a later Partido Carlista acitivist and writer.<ref>Josep Miralles Climent, ''Los heterodoxos de la causa'', Madrid 2001, {{ISBN|9788483742433}}, pp. 21, 132. Similar claim in ''Xavier Ferrer Bonet'' entry, [in:] ''El Corte Ingl√©s'' service, available [https://www.elcorteingles.es/bio/xavier-ferrer-bonet/ here]</ref> [[Augusto Ferrer-Dalmau|Augusto Ferrer-Dalmau Nieto]], a well-known painter specializing in historical military themes, is the great-grandson of Melchor's brother.<ref>''Fe, un rom√°ntico homenaje juvenil del Pintor de Batallas al Tradicionalismo'', [in:] ''Ahora Informaci√≥n'' service 13.02.17, available [http://www.ahorainformacion.es/blog/fe-un-romantico-homenaje-juvenil-del-pintor-de-batallas-al-tradicionalismo/ here]</ref>
==Restoration== [[File:El Correo Catalan.png|thumb|left|''El Correo Catalan'' mastheads]] With his father a Carlist combatant and older brothers engaged in Carlist activities, Melchor followed suit in his youth. During academic years he joined the Barcelona section of Juventud Tradicionalista. From the onset he demonstrated interest in the realm of communication in general and newspapers in particular. Engaged in Secci√≥n de Prensa and becoming president of "sub-secci√≥n de ventas" he supported sales of Traditionalist papers beyond usual distribution channels;<ref>''La Bandera Regional'' 19.02.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000373167&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> he was also member of Junta Directiva of Secci√≥n de Propaganda.<ref>''La Bandera Ragional'' 10.12.10. available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000373204&interno=S&posicion=6&presentacion=pagina here], ''La Defensa'' 26.02.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1095516&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> First contributing minor pieces to youth and party bulletins, in 1910 he formally entered the editorial board of ''[[:es:El Correo Catalan|El Correo Catalan]]'',<ref>''El Norte'' 06.12.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3069368&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> an established Barcelona-based daily and a regional Carlist mouthpiece. It is not clear what his work consisted of and whether the young Ferrer published pieces of his own;<ref>''El Correo Catalan'' is not digitalised yet and its issues are not available for consultation online</ref> he kept working for Correo until 1914.<ref>''La Cruz'' 08.03.19, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3047603&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
Though Ferrer delivered lectures at meetings of Carlist paramilitary organisation [[requet√©]]<ref>''Diario de Valencia'' 26.02.14, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000187347&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> he had no military experience himself when in 1914, heavily influenced by [[Charles Maurras|Maurras]] and admirer of [[L'Action Fran√ßaise]], he decided to join the French army and fight the Germans. The Republican press ridiculed him as a future field marshal,<ref>''El Pueblo'' 08.11.14, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000190608&interno=S&posicion=4&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> though with no news of his whereabouts Ferrer was first feared dead in combat.<ref>''La Correspondencia de Valencia'' 10.12.14, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000241356&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In fact things turned out oddly, yet the entire episode is far from clear. According to contemporary press the pro-German stand of ''Correo''<ref>due to its perceived pro-German stand ''El Correo Catalan'' was not allowed to be distributed in France, ''El Correo Espa√±ol'' 16.01.15, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029773881&page=2 here]</ref> combined with anonymous denunciation<ref>anonymous denunciation was attributed to Esteban Rold√°n Oliart. Rold√°n defended himself in a separate piece, compare Esteban Roldan, ''Francia y los cat√≥licos espa√±oles'', Barcelona 1915, pp. 101-103, available [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k990628k/f103.item.r=%22melchor%20ferrer%22 here]. Ferrer fimself publicly remained silent on his (former?) friend; he noted merely that in 1920 Roldan moved to America, see his ''Historia del tradicionalismo espa√±ol'' vol. XXIX, Seville 1960, p. 76</ref> cost Ferrer arrest; presumed to be a spy, he was [[court-martialled]] in [[Lyon]] but spared a sentence ending up in [[L√©gion √©trang√®re]],<ref>''El Norte'' 13.01.15, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3067321&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> the fate he accepted with resignation as result of his idealistic and perhaps childish ‚Äúchiquillada‚Äù.<ref>''El Correo Espa√±ol'' 10.01.15, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029773851&page=2 here]</ref> Other accounts either deny the arrest episode or simply claim that Ferrer volunteered to the legion.<ref>''El Correo Espa√±ol'' 16.01.15, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029773881&page=2 here], Rafael Gambra, ''Melchor Ferrer y la ‚ÄûHistoria del tardicionalismo'' [sic!] ''espa√±ol‚Äù'', Sevilla 1979, p. 3 [start page assumed as page 1, no original pagination]</ref> This way or another, Ferrer served in the Foreign Legion in [[Champagne (province)|Champagne]]<ref>''Espa√±a'' 20.03.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003384883&page=7 here]</ref> and grew to [[Non-commissioned officer|NCO]]<ref>Mundet Gifre 1980, Gambra 1979, p. 3</ref> before being released in 1918. [[File:Junta de Biarritz.jpg|thumb|Magna Junta de Biarritz, 1919]] In late 1918 and early 1919 Ferrer spent some time in [[Paris]]; it is there he entered the entourage of the Carlist pretender [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]].<ref>''El Correo Espa√±ol'' 08.03.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029781213&page=3 here]</ref> The two found common ground, not unlikely given their shared [[francophilia]]. As a result, upon his return to Spain in the spring Ferrer was nominated director pol√≠tico of ''[[:es:El Correo Espa√±ol|El Correo Espa√±ol]]'',<ref>in May, see ''El Correo Espa√±ol'' 02.05.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029781451&page=1 here], or in April, see ''La Correspondencia de Espa√±a'' 12.04.19, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7141357&interno=S&posicion=6&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> the Madrid daily serving as national Carlist mouthpiece; his task was to ensure loyalty of the newspaper, so far controlled by the dissenting [[Mellismo|Mellista faction]].<ref>''El Correo Espa√±ol'' 23.09.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029782164&page=1 here]</ref> As he was largely unknown beyond Catalonia<ref>"hasta entonces desconocido en las filas carlistas", Roman Oyarzun, ''La historia del carlismo'', Madrid 1979, p. 497</ref> some Carlist heavyweights suspected dirty tricks on part of Don Jaime's secretary [[Francisco Mart√≠n Melgar y Rodr√≠guez|Melgar]] and asked for confirmation, which finally permitted Ferrer to assume his post.<ref>Melchor Ferrer, ''Historia del tradicionalismo espa√±ol'', vol. XXIX, Sevilla 1960, p. 114</ref> His mission proved successful; though Mellista defection decimated Carlist ranks, ''Correo'' maintained loyalty to the claimant. Ferrer remained in close touch with his king; he used to travel to Paris for consultations<ref>''La Correspondencia de Espa√±a'' 25.05.19, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7140918&interno=S&posicion=6&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and in late 1919 took part in the massive gathering known as Magna Junta de Biarritz,<ref>''La Correspondencia de Espa√±a'' 12.12.19, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7142802&interno=S&posicion=5&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> where he represented [[New Castile (Spain)|Castilla La Nueva]].<ref>Juan Mar√≠a Roma (ed.), ''Album hist√≥rico del carlismo'', Barcelona 1935, p. 285</ref> He also toured Spain, trying to save what was left of the crumbling Carlist organisation.<ref>''El Correo Espa√±ol'' 21.10.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029782294&page=2 here], also ''El Correo Espa√±ol'' 21.12.19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029782545&page=1 here]</ref> Ferrer's term in ''Correo'' lasted until mid-1920; it is not clear why he left the daily.<ref>in May 1920 Arsenio de Izaga became the new jefe of ''El Correo Espa√±ol'', ''El Correo Espa√±ol'' 27.05.20, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0029783202&page=1 here]</ref>
==Dictatorship, Republic and War== [[File:Jaime de Borb√≥n, in El Mundo Grafico 7 10 1931 p√°gina 24.jpg|thumb|160px|left|[[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]], 1920s]] It does not seem that Ferrer left ''Correo'' because of discrepancies with his king; quite to the contrary, in the movement plagued by defections and by some considered dead he remained among most loyal individuals and a bulwark against the Mellistas.<ref>Gambra 1979, p. 3</ref> His position was confirmed when at unspecified time in the 1920s<ref>when featured in Carlist press in 1927, Ferrer was listed simply as "ex-director of ''El Correo Espa√±ol''" with no currently held function named, compare ''El Eco de Gerona'' 24.12.27, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3062738&interno=S&posicion=4&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Ferrer became secretario pariculario ‚Äì sort of a personal secretary ‚Äì to Don Jaime himself. None of the sources consulted clarifies whether he moved to Paris when performing the new job, yet his contributions kept appearing in numerous dailies<ref>like ''El Correo Catal√°n'' (Barcelona), ''El Pensamiento Navarro'' (Pamplona) and ''Gil Blas'' (Santander), contributing also to minor titles like ''Diario de Villanueva i Geltru'', compare e.g. [http://xacpremsa.cultura.gencat.cat/pandora/cgi-bin/Pandora.exe?xslt=ejemplar;comarca=Garraf;publication_id=ac.garraf.vilanova.i.la.geltru.diario.de.vilanova.i.la.geltru;place=Vilanova%20i%20la%20Geltr%C3%BA;publication=Diario%20de%20Vilanova%20i%20la%20Geltr%C3%BA;day=16;month=04;year=1924;page=0002;id=0001320004;collection=premsa;url_high=premsa_pages/AC%20Garraf/Garraf/Vilanova%20i%20la%20Geltr%C3%BA/Diario%20de%20Vilanova%20i%20la%20Geltr%C3%BA/1924/192404/19240416/19240416-0002.pdf;lang=ca;archivo=AC%20Garraf;encoding=utf-8 here]</ref> and periodicals,<ref>like ''La Bandera Regional'', ''La Trinchera'', ''La Naci√≥'', ''El Radical'', ''El Guerillero'', ''Patria'', ''Espa√±a'', ''Misi√≥n'', ''Iberia'', ''Gr√°fico Legitimista'', ''La Protesta'' and ''Reacci√≥'', R.S.H. 1980, p. 162</ref> including the French ones.<ref>allegedly Ferrer contributed also to ''L‚ÄôAction Francaise'' and ''La Croix'', see ''ABC'' 13.06.65, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1965/06/13/070.html here]; however, a digital archive of both papers does not reveal any items signed by Ferrer, compare the ''Gallica'' service, available [http://gallica.bnf.fr/services/engine/search/sru?operation=searchRetrieve&version=1.2&query=%28gallica%20adj%20%22Melchor%20Ferrer%22%29&suggest=0 here]</ref> Some scholars suggest he might have been involved in efforts to animate the Requet√© organisation across Spain and that Ferrer might have also contributed to loose preparations to stage an eventually cancelled Carlist anti-primoderiverista coup in [[Seu d'urgell|Seu d‚ÄôUrgell]] in 1928;<ref>Eduardo Gonz√°lez Calleja, ''Paramilitaritzaci√≥ i viol√©ncia pol√≠tica a l‚ÄôEspanya del primer terc de segle: el requet√© tradicionalista (1900-1936)'', [in:] ''Revista de Girona'' 147 (1991), pp. 71, 76. In the late 1920s Ferrer allegedly formed part of an informal Jaimist nationwide network known as "La Protesta"; some scholars claim that he was active in the Barcelona cell, Jordi Canal, ''El carlismo'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|8420639478}}, p. 285. Formed mostly by the youth, the grouplets engaged in conspiracy against the regime. Its format emphasized mobilization and search for wider social basis rather than anti-primoderiverista activities, though at one point the Barcelona hotheads considered staging a coup in [[La Seu d'Urgell]], see Jos√© Carlos Clemente Mu√±oz, ''El carlismo en el novecientos espa√±ol (1876‚Äì1936)'', Madrid 1999, {{ISBN|8483741539}}, p. 74, Robert Vallverd√∫ i Mart√≠, El Carlisme Catal√† Durant La Segona Rep√∫blica Espanyola 1931-1936, Barcelona 2008, {{ISBN|9788478260805}}, p. 19. The Madrid cell was led by Francisco Carlos Melgar; other grouplets were active also in Vascongadas, Navarre and Aragon. "La Protesta" was somewhat at odds with generally passive policy of the Carlist executive; some authors claim that the Catalan leadership was aware of its activities but preferred not to intervene - Vallverd√∫ i Mart√≠ 2008, p. 19 - though not necessarily with position of the claimant; since 1926 openly opposing Primo, in his Paris residence Don Jaime remained in touch with the Catalanist and liberal exiles, Canal 2000, p. 285</ref> Ferrer himself points rather to his older brother Antonio.<ref>Melchor Ferrer, ''Historia del tradicionalismo espa√±ol'', vol. XXIX, Sevilla 1960, pp. 177, 183-184</ref> Another scholar claims that Ferrer remained the secretary of Don Jaime until the Carlist king passed away in late 1931.<ref>Mercedes V√°zquez de Prada, ''Auge y declive del tradicionalismo carlista (1957-1967)'', Madrid 2016, {{ISBN|9788416558407}}, p. 41, Jacek Bartyzel, ''Melchor Ferrer'', [in:] ''My≈õl Konserwatywna'' service 04.06.15, available [http://myslkonserwatywna.pl/melchor-ferrer/ here]</ref>
In late 1930 Ferrer assumed management of ''Diario Monta√±es'',<ref>''Heraldo de Madrid'' 03.11.30, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000958110&page=4 here]</ref> a conservative [[Santander, Spain|Santander]] daily strongly flavored with Traditionalism. Circumstances of his appointment are not known; it is neither clear how it could have been reconciled with alleged work for Don Jaime. Ferrer's term in Santander lasted almost 5 years and seems rather successful, at least in terms of mobilizing support for the cause; during the Republican period the [[Cantabria]]n Carlism enjoyed its revival. Ferrer contributed also by attending various meetings, where he used to give lectures.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 04.02.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000494417&page=4 here]</ref> In 1931 he published one of his few theoretical booklets<ref>titled ''S√≠ntesis del programa de la Comuni√≥n Tradicionalista Espa√±ola'' (Santander, 1932)</ref> and penned pieces to a Santanderine review ''Tradici√≥n''. Apart from those discussing ideological threads, some were also his first incursions into the field of history, like piece on aristocratic titles conceded by Carlist monarchs<ref>Melchor Ferrer, ''Titulos Nobiliarios Carlistas'', [in:] ''Tradici√≥n'' 28 (1934), pp. 89-91, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000208717&interno=S&presentacion=pagina&posicion=27 here]</ref> or a summary of party's political leadership during the previous half a century.<ref>Melchor Ferrer, ''La direcci√≥n pol√≠tica de la Comuni√≥n Tradicionalista desde 1876'', [in:] ''Tradici√≥n'' 37 (1934), pp. 296-302, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000208723&interno=S&presentacion=pagina&posicion=14 here]</ref> [[File:Ja√©n desde el mirador - Olga Berrios.jpg|thumb|[[Ja√©n, Spain|Ja√©n]] (current view)]] In early 1935 Ferrer moved from the coast of [[Bay of Biscay|Biscay]] to [[Andalusia]], where he assumed management of the local daily ''Eco de Ja√©n''.<ref>''La Naci√≥n'' 14.01.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026335891&page=7 here]</ref> A recently established newspaper, it was in fact successor to ''El Pueblo Cat√≥lico'', a Traditionalist daily issued since 1893; the latter underwent ownership changes and finally closed, to be reborn under a new name.<ref>Ram√≥n Reig Garc√≠a, ''La comunicaci√≥n en Andaluc√≠a: historia, estructura y nuevas tecnolog√≠as'', Sevilla 2011, {{ISBN|9788493907808}}, p. 121</ref> When Ferrer took over the daily was still shaped by its previous [[Integrism (Spain)|Integrist]] heritage; Ferrer brought it fully into Carlist orthodoxy and converted into a modern newspaper. Like in Santander, he supported the Carlist buildup by attending local meetings and mobilizing support.<ref>''ABC'' 17.11.35, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1935/11/17/034.html here]</ref> It is not clear whether Ferrer contributed to or was even aware of the Carlist anti-Republican conspiracy; one author claims the [[Spanish coup of July 1936|1936 coup]] caught him by surprise. ''Eco de Ja√©n'' operated until late July, when first its premises were ransacked and then the paper was turned into the mouthpiece of local [[Popular Front (Spain)|Frente Popular]].<ref>Antonio Checa Godoy, ''Prensa y partidos pol√≠ticos durante la II Rep√∫blica'', Salamanca 1989, {{ISBN|9788474815214}}, p. 202</ref> Having lost his job Ferrer was subject to unspecified persecution and harassment,<ref>Gambra 1979, p. 4</ref> yet he survived the [[Red Terror (Spain)|revolutionary terror]]<ref>during republican terror in Ja√©n popular tribunals sentenced 60 individuals to death and further 70 to lifetime incarceration in 1936 only; number of victims of extrajudicial repression is not known, Luis Garrido Gonz√°lez, ''Ja√©n y la guerra civil (1936-1939)'', [in:] ''Bolet√≠n. Instituto de Estudios Giennenses'' 198 (2008), p. 204</ref> and following almost 3 years in the [[Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)|Republican zone]] endured to see Ja√©n captured by the [[Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)|Nationalists]] in late March 1939.
==Early Francoism== [[File:Anuncio del hotel.jpg|thumb|left|[[Seville]], early post-war period]] Shortly after the Nationalist takeover of [[Ja√©n, Spain|Ja√©n]] Ferrer moved to [[Seville]]; the local Carlist daily ''[[:es:La Uni√≥n (Sevilla)|La Uni√≥n]]'' was subject to heavy censorship measures and its head [[:es:Domingo Tejera de Quesada|Domingo Tejera]] ceded management to Ferrer in hope to spare the newspaper. However, the [[Francoism|Francoist]] structures were determined not to tolerate dissenting party titles and ''La Uni√≥n'' closed on December 31, 1939.<ref>Cristina Barreiro Gordillo, ''El carlismo y su red de prensa en la Segunda Rep√∫blica'', Madrid 2003, {{ISBN|9788497390378}}, p. 320</ref> Ferrer's position went from bad to worse when he refused to join the new state party, [[Falange Espa√±ola Tradicionalista]], and its syndicate press structures; as a result, in 1941 he got his press license revoked.<ref>Bartyzel 2015</ref> It is not clear how Ferrer made a living; at unspecified time he assumed teaching duties in the local [[:es:Escuela de San Telmo|Escuela N√°utica San Telmo]] and at preparatory courses to entry exams to military academies.<ref>like Academia Militar General in Zaragoza, aviation academy and army academy, R.S.H. 1980, p. 162</ref> It is in the early 1940s that he started publishing ''Historia del tradicionalismo espa√±ol'',<ref>the title is currently referred to either as "Historia del tradicionalismo espa√±ol" or "Historia del Tradicionalismo Espa√±ol". The original title was fully capitalised, hence it is difficult to ascertain which orthographic version is original</ref> a series which would become the source of income but which also in few years would earn him ‚Äì still fairly unknown in the Carlist realm across Spain ‚Äì enormous prestige nationwide.
Since the mid-1940s Ferrer was taking part in resumed meetings of Consejo Nacional Carlista, the National Carlist executive. The nature of his mandate is unclear, as he did not held formal posts in the party structures;<ref>Gambra 1979, p. 1</ref> it was probably related to his personal friendship with the Carlist leader [[Manuel Fal Conde]], also resident of Seville. Confronted with growing fragmentation and bewilderment among the Traditionalists Ferrer maintained total loyalty to the regent [[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Don Javier]] and used his pen to fight off competing factions. His 1946 booklet ''Observaciones de un viejo carlista a unas cartas del Conde de Rodezno'' was aimed against those advancing [[Infante Juan, Count of Barcelona|Don Juan]] as a legitimate Carlist heir. The 1948 booklet ''Observaciones de un viejo carlista sobre las pretensiones de un Pr√≠ncipe al trono de Espa√±a'' was aimed against [[Carloctavismo]]; offering "a ultranza" defense of the regency in insulting style Ferrer ridiculed [[Archduke Karl Pius of Austria, Prince of Tuscany|Carlos VIII]] and the cause of "farsa carloenchufista que encubre un carlofascismo de ocasi√≥n".<ref>Francisco de las Heras y Borrero, ''Un pretendiente desconocido. Carlos de Habsburgo. El otro candidato de Franco'', Madrid 2004, {{ISBN|8497725565}}, p. 77</ref> Confronted with apparent stabilization of the regime in 1949 Ferrer advocated change of the Carlist strategy; instead of courting potentially rebellious generals he suggested popular mobilization.<ref>Manuel Martorell P√©rez, ''La continuidad ideol√≥gica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis in Historia Contemporanea, Universidad Nacional de Educaci√≥n a Distancia], Valencia 2009, p. 328</ref> [[File:RequeteViladot.JPG|thumb|160px|''[[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Javier I]]'', 1950s]] It is not clear whether uncompromising position of Ferrer from the onset encompassed also suggestions to replace the regency with personal Don Javier's claim to the throne; this stand prevailed among the Carlist executive in the early 1950s and Ferrer remained in line. He co-worked to prepare documents, made public during the Eucharistic Congress in Barcelona in 1952, which acknowledged Don Javier as a legitimist monarch.<ref>C√©sar Alcal√°, ''D. Mauricio de Sivatte. Una biograf√≠a pol√≠tica (1901-1980)'', Barcelona 2001, {{ISBN|8493109797}}, p. 99</ref> Unwavering loyalty to the Borb√≥n-Parmas, which was already becoming sort of Ferrer's trademark, was further demonstrated in a booklet released in 1955; anonymous though generally attributed to Ferrer, it was distributed by the Carlist academic youth mostly in [[Madrid]]. Designed as response to earlier Franco's meeting with Don Juan and increasing prospects of [[Alfonsism|Alfonsists]] restoration,<ref>also as response to abusive public Franco‚Äôs comments, which reduced Carlism to a bunch of offshoots following a foreign prince, almost traitors</ref> the booklet denounced such a possibility as treason to the spirit of July 1936, allegedly shaped by a pact between the Carlists and the military.<ref>Martorell P√©rez 2009, p. 377, Javier Lavard√≠n, ''Historia del ultimo pretendiente a la corona de Espa√±a'', Paris 1976, p. 19</ref>
==Mid-Francoism== [[File:Retrato D. Jose Luis Zamanillo Gonzalez-Camino por D. Sansegundo Castaneda (1949).jpg|thumb|160px|left|[[Jose Luis Zamanillo Gonzalez-Camino|Zamanillo]]]] Ferrer was very uneasy about 1955 Fal's dismissal from political leadership and pro-collaborationist turn of the party.<ref>Mercedes V√°zquez de Prada, ''El nuevo rumbo pol√≠tico del carlismo hacia la colaboraci√≥n con el r√©gimen (1955-56)'', [in:] ''Hispania'' 69 (2009), p. 190, V√°zquez de Prada 2016, p. 40</ref> During a 1956 meeting of the executive<ref>Lavardin 1976, p. 27</ref> he warned about a forthcoming Franco-Juanista maneuver dubbed "Plan Artajo",<ref>V√°zquez de Prada 2009, p. 192, V√°zquez de Prada 2016, p. 41</ref> yet he remained totally loyal to his king, to the new strategy he sponsored and to the new party leader, [[Jos√© Mar√≠a Valiente Soriano|Jos√© Mar√≠a Valiente]]; he remained on fairly good terms with the latter.<ref>see e.g. friendly if not intimate letters exchanged between Valiente and Ferrer, V√°zquez de Prada 2016, p. 91</ref> In the late 1950s Ferrer's historiographic production assumed already massive scope and earned him enormous prestige in the party ranks. It was reflected by his continuous presence at executive sessions; in 1960 he was even entrusted with writing sort of a rulebook for organization of Consejo Nacional sittings.<ref>Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''El naufragio de las ortodoxias. El carlismo 1962-1977'', Pamplona 1997, {{ISBN|8431315644}}, p. 84</ref> In 1961 he entered a newly formed Comisi√≥n de Cultura; as censorship eased, he contributed to Comisi√≥n's mouthpiece ''Reconquista'',<ref>V√°zquez de Prada 2016, p. 119</ref> bulletins of Circulos V√°zquez de Mella and other new periodicals like ''[[Montejurra (magazine)|Montejurra]]''.<ref>also ''Informaciones'', ''Cristiandad'' and ''Siempre'', R.S.H. 1980, p. 162</ref>
Until the early 1960s Ferrer's actual impact on Carlist politics remained marginal;<ref>Ferrer "nunca se habia metido en pol√≠tica", V√°zquez de Prada 2016, p. 188</ref> his position was rather this of a patriarch, scarcely involved in day-to-day business. This changed when discrepancies between the old Traditionalist guard and the unorthodox Carlist youth became visible. Ferrer tended to side with the latter, guided not that much by their theoretical innovations but rather by their absolute and unconditional loyalty to the Borb√≥n-Parmas. In 1961 he opposed attempts to set up a board co-ordinating Carlist propaganda,<ref>it might be interesting to note that back in 1935 Ferrer supported co-ordination of Carlist print activities, Francisco Javier Capistegui, ''Parad√≥jicos reaccionarios: la modernidad contra la Rep√∫blica de la Comuni√≥n Tradicionalista'', [in :] ''Argonauta Espa√±ol'' 9 (2012), available [https://argonauta.revues.org/1409 here]</ref> put forward by orthodoxes concerned with new tones advanced by periodicals like ''Azada y Asta''.<ref>V√°zquez de Prada 2016, p. 120</ref> Ferrer remained also on excellent terms with leader of the youth, Don Javier's oldest son [[Carlos Hugo, Duke of Parma|Don Carlos Hugo]],<ref>Ferrer was "muy vinculado a Carlos Hugo e Irene", Lavardin 1976, p. 250</ref> though initially he was perplexed by the bachelor status of the prince.<ref>conscious of dynastical problems caused resulting from Jaime III‚Äôs lack of offspring, in 1961 Ferrer urged Junta Nacional to formally raise the issue with Don Carlos Hugo, V√°zquez de Prada 2016, p. 145, Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 76</ref> When the Traditionalists, led by [[Jos√© Luis Zamanillo Gonz√°lez-Camino|Jos√© Luis Zamanillo]], started to mount an opposition strategy against the Hugocarlistas, Ferrer did not hesitate to confront them. In 1962 he accused Zamanillo ‚Äì due to his requet√© past enormously respected in the party ranks ‚Äì of inactivity.<ref>Lavardin 1976, p. 143</ref> [[File:Charles-Hugues de Bourbon-Parme.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Carlos Hugo]] (1964)]] In 1963 the showdown between Zamanillo-led Traditionalists and [[Ram√≥n Mass√≥ Tarruella|Mass√≥]]-led Hugocarlistas was already in full swing. Ferrer threw his authority behind the latter and released a memorandum,<ref>titled ''Breves consideraciones a una posici√≥n inadecuada adoptada por carlistas disidentes del dieciocho de julio''</ref> charging Zamanillo and the review ''Siempre'' with mounting a pro-Juanista plot. Dubbing himself "the bellboy of Carlism" Ferrer noted he was happy to keep the door open for Zamanillo to leave,<ref>Lavardin 1976, pp. 148-149</ref> in aggressive and mocking tone lambasting also other dissidents like [[Maurici de Sivatte i de Bobadilla|Sivatte]] or [[Jes√∫s Cora y Lira|Cora]].<ref>e.g. he ridiculed [[Maurici de Sivatte i de Bobadilla|Mauricio de Sivatte]] as "Su Alteza Real Don Mauricio" and mocked [[Jes√∫s Cora y Lira]] as "inventor de pretendientes m√°s conocido pos Su Excellencia Don Jes√∫s", dubbing both "pseudocarlistas". Some of those approached - like del Mazo - backtracked, but some ‚Äì like [[Francisco El√≠as de Tejada y Sp√≠nola|El√≠as de Tejada]] - fought back, lambasting Ferrer‚Äôs paper as "chabacanas majader√≠as", Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, pp. 183-184</ref> His stand might have tipped the balance; Zamanillo was expulsed and control of the party slipped to the Hugocarlistas.<ref>V√°zquez de Prada 2016, p. 188</ref> Last years of Ferrer's life are marked by attempts to reinforce the position of Don Carlos Hugo. In 1964 he fathered a booklet intended to demonstrate the rights of Borb√≥n-Parmas to Spanish citizenship, a document the prince had in hand when talking to [[Francisco Franco|Franco]].<ref>V√°zquez de Prada 2016, p. 224; the document was partially based on legal opinions gathered earlier, Lavardin 1976, p. 211</ref> Then he drafted analysis advancing their right to the Spanish throne;<ref>V√°zquez de Prada 2016, p. 240</ref> it was used during a grand Carlist gathering in 1965 in [[Attnang-Puchheim|Puchheim]], where Don Javier confirmed his royal claim.<ref>Lavardin 1976, p. 250</ref> Ferrer himself was already unable to attend;<ref>Daniel Jes√∫s Garc√≠a Riol, ''La resistencia tradicionalista a la renovaci√≥n ideol√≥gica del carlismo (1965-1973)'' [PhD thesis UNED], Madrid 2015, p. 50</ref> he was rewarded by Orden de la Legitimidad Proscrita, a high Carlist honor awarded by the claimants.<ref>Jos√© Carlos Clemente, ''El Carlismo en la Espa√±a de Franco: Bases Documentales 1936-1977'', Madrid 1994, {{ISBN|9788424506704}}, p. 45, R.S.H. 1980, p. 162</ref>
==Historian== [[File:Domingo Tejera de Quesada.jpg|thumb|left|160px|[[:es:Domingo Tejera de Quesada|Domingo Tejera]]]] Ferrer was educated to be an [[engineer]] and his professional career is usually described as this of a periodista,<ref>Gambra 1979, p. 1</ref> though perhaps not a very successful one.<ref>Gambra 1979, p. 2</ref> He demonstrated no particular interest in history until in the mid-1930s he penned a few articles discussing the Carlist past,<ref>Melchor Ferrer, ''Titulos Nobiliarios Carlistas'', [in:] ''Tradici√≥n'' 28 (1934), pp. 89-91</ref> especially ''La direcci√≥n pol√≠tica de la Comuni√≥n Tradicionalista desde 1876''.<ref>Melchor Ferrer, ''La direcci√≥n pol√≠tica de la Comuni√≥n Tradicionalista desde 1876'', [in:] ''Tradici√≥n'' 37 (1934), pp. 296-302</ref> According to some authors already during his idle years in Ja√©n of the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]] he started gathering materials for a general history of Carlism.<ref>Canal 2000, p. 408</ref> According to others he acted on suggestion of Fal Conde, who in 1939 proposed that in order to maintain Carlist identity in wake of political amalgamation into one Francoist state party, a general history of Carlism was badly needed.<ref>Mundet Gifre 1980, Gambra 1979, p. 5</ref> One more group of scholars claim that Ferrer and his collaborators commenced their work to counter ''Historia de la guerra civil y de los partidos liberal y carlista'' by [[:es:Antonio Pirala|Antonio Pirala Criado]], a 19th-century study which until 1939 was the only work serving as the overall history of the movement.<ref>Jos√© Ram√≥n Barreiro Fern√°ndez, ''O liberalismo nos seus contextos: un estado da cuesti√≥n'', Santiago de Compostela 2008, {{ISBN|9788497509190}}, p. 39</ref> In 1939 a former Carlist militant [[Rom√°n Oyarzun Oyarzun|Roman Oyarzun]] published the first concise historiographic account of Carlism, ''Historia del Carlismo'', yet his work was greeted with mixed feelings among the Carlists. Many considered Oyarzun's book an unorthodox attempt and were near to dismissing it altogether,<ref>Lopezarra [Francisco L√≥pez Sanz] following a spate of criticism concluded that at least Oyarzun "made an effort and his intention was good", quoted after Oyarzun 1944, p. 502, compare also his polemics with Traditionalist critics in the section ''Autocr√≠tica y cr√≠tica de los cr√≠ticos'', Oyarzun 1944</ref> still calling for sort of an "official" Carlist history.
In 1941 Ferrer and two other Seville-based authors, Jos√© F. Acedo Castilla and Domingo Tejera de Quesada, published in the local Editorial Cat√≥lica Espa√±ola<ref>all series except volumes XII-XIII was issued by a Sevilla publishing house Editorial Cat√≥lica Espa√±ola</ref> the first volume of ''Historia del tradicionalismo espa√±ol'', intended as a general, in-depth history of Carlism. The team kept working on further volumes, though contribution of each of its members is difficult to gauge;<ref>in many brief references the whole series is attributed to Ferrer only, see. e.g. Mark Lawrence, ''Spain's First Carlist War, 1833-40'', London 2014, {{ISBN|9781137401755}}, p. 17. Some highligt Ferrer and refer to Tejera and Acedo as "his collaborators", see e.g. A. J. P. Taylor, ''Oxford History of Modern Europe: The Struggle for Mastery in Europe 1845-1918'', London 1966, p. 702</ref> Tejera passed away in 1944 yet all 11 volumes published until 1949 were attributed to all three authors. As Acedo left orthodox Carlism, starting volume XII Ferrer was named as the sole author. He managed to keep momentum and there were 18 volumes published in 15 years until 1956; during the following 5 years Ferrer completed subsequent 11 volumes, in 1960 releasing volume XXIX and bringing the narrative to the year of 1931. [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|Carlist standard]] Ferrer kept working on consecutive volumes, yet he did not live to see them released.<ref>Ferrer was also planning to publish encyclopaedia of Carlism and the volume of material gathered is described as enormous, Canal 2000, p. 408. According to some, ''Diccionario hist√≥rico del carlismo'' by Josep Carles Clemente was a work which "ha realizado el proyecto que en su d√≠a inici√≥ Melchor Ferrer", see opinion of Manuel Martorell Perez at ''Pamiela'' publishing house website, available [http://www.pamiela.com/es/ensayo/ensayo-y-testimonio/diccionario-historico-del-carlismo-detail here]. He left also a few manuscripts: ''Musa carlista: El tema carlista en la poesia, El pensamiento pol√≠tico del Conde de Montemol√≠n, Un pensador olvidado: Fray Magin Ferrer'' and ''Los bonos del Tesoro y las emisiones carlistas de deuda'', Gambra 1979, p. 4</ref> According to one author, the delay was caused by problems with censorship;<ref>Gambra 1979, p. 5</ref> eventually volume XXX, covering the period of 1931-1936, was edited posthumously by Enrique Rold√°n Gonz√°lez and released in 1979, attributed to Ferrer only.<ref>Cain Som√© Laserna, ''El carlismo andaluz: estado de la cuesti√≥n'', [in:] Alejandra Ibarra Aguirregabiria (ed.), ''No es pa√≠s para jovenes'', Madrid 2012, {{ISBN|9788498606362}}, p. 9</ref> In total ''Historia del tradicionalismo espa√±ol'' amounts to around 9,300 pages; each volume includes some 50-150 pages of documental appendices and a bibliography. The series clearly focuses on military history; the [[First Carlist War]] is covered in 15 volumes and the Third Carlist War is treated in 4 volumes, while 32 years in-between both conflicts deserved just 5 volumes; 33 years of 1876-1909 are discussed in just 1 volume and 22 years of 1909-1931 in another.<ref>I (1941): ''El pensamiento espa√±ol desde los tiempos de San Isidro hasta la sublevaci√≥n mas√≥nica de 1820''; II (1941): ''El precarlismo.
